## Summary

**Source:** World of Reel | **Author:** Jordan Ruimy | **Date:** August 19, 2019 *(Note: The date appears inconsistent with the article's content, which references 2025/2026 events — the actual publication date is likely mid-2025)*

---

### Key Facts & Details:

- **Distribution situation:** Neon is releasing Julia Ducournau's *Alpha* (a 2025 Cannes title) in only **two theaters** this weekend, including one in the Bronx, with little advance notice — effectively a quiet dump.
- **Critical reception:** The film scored **47 on Metacritic**, described as poor reviews that have severely damaged its commercial prospects.
- **Festival circuit:** Following its Cannes debut, *Alpha* was **absent from major fall festivals** (Telluride, NYFF, TIFF, Chicago), with only a stop at the **London BFI Fest**.
- **Possible wider release:** There is unconfirmed word that Neon *might* give the film a **March 2026 release**, though the author expresses skepticism.
- **Neon's competing priorities:** Neon has a crowded awards slate with *It Was Just An Accident*, *Sentimental Value*, *The Secret Agent*, and *Sirat*, leaving little room for *Alpha*.

### Author's Opinion (Jordan Ruimy, World of Reel):
Ruimy found *Alpha* "audacious and admirable, yet ultimately overambitious," describing the second half as descending into "Lynchian chaos." He sees virtually no awards prospects and a very limited audience remaining for the film.

## Summary

This article from *Screen* (December 5, 2025), written by Rebecca Leffler, covers the **12th edition of Cannes Critics' Week's "Next Step" programme**, running December 6–12, 2025, in France.

### Key Facts:
- **Ten international filmmakers** whose short films previously premiered at Cannes Critics' Week were selected to develop their first feature films through the programme.
- The programme takes place at the Moulin d'Andé residence in Normandy, followed by Paris networking events.
- Mentors include script consultants Yacine Badday, Philippe Barrière, Leyla Bouzid, Franco Lolli, Thomas van Zuylen, and producer Juliette Lepoutre, as well as music composers.
- **One project will receive a €2,500 Next Step prize at the Cannes Film Festival in May 2026**, with a residency at Moulin d'Andé.
- To date, 45 completed feature films have emerged from Next Step, including 2025 titles. Seven further Next Step films are expected to premiere in 2026, with nine heading into production.

**France Named 'Creative Country of the Year' for 2026 at Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity**
France has been named the 'Creative Country of the Year' for 2026 at the 73rd Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity, an annual award recognizing nations that consistently demonstrate exceptional creativity and long-term commitment to advancing social progress and economic growth. The honor reflects France's deep-rooted leadership across advertising, fashion, craftsmanship, technology, culture, and business. According to LIONS CEO Simon Cook, France has a strong creative output and rich cultural heritage, with over €10 billion invested by the French government in more than 20,000 creative enterprises since 2020 and a cultural and creative industries sector generating €92 billion annually. France has consistently ranked among the top 10 global performers at the festival since its inception, placing fourth in 2024. The festival has been held in Cannes since 1984, and France’s cultural spirit is deeply embedded in its identity. As part of the recognition, a series of France-themed events—including showcases, celebrations, forums, and brand activations—will take place during the 2026 festival. Special social events will also bring together French and global creative leaders. David Lisnard emphasized the significance of the honor, noting the longstanding historical ties between Cannes Lions and France, and highlighting France’s 'France 2030' national investment plan, which prioritizes cultural content production and immersive technologies as strategic pillars. France has won 1,603 Lions awards and 39 Grand Prix since the festival began, with its first Grand Prix in 1955 and its first Lion in 1954 for a Camay soap ad. In 2025, French brand AXA led all companies with 13 awards, including three for 'AXA - Three Words' by Publicis Conseil Paris. Over 250 French creatives have served as festival judges, with 18 chairing the jury. To support emerging talent, a special initiative will allow French representatives to gift free passes to first-time attendees. The project is backed by AACC, Mairie de Cannes, Publicis, Havas, IAA, and Le Club des Directeurs Artistiques. The 2026 Cannes Lions Festival will run from June 22 to 26, with registration now open.

**Il suono di una caduta: Exclusive Clip from Mascha Schilinski's Cannes Prize-Winning Film**
Sky TG24 has released an exclusive clip for 'Il suono di una caduta' (original title: 'Sound of Falling'), the second feature film by German director Mascha Schilinski. The film, which won the Jury Prize at the 2025 Cannes Film Festival and is Germany's official submission for the 2026 Oscar for Best International Feature, is set in a farm in northern Germany and portrays a century of female memory through trauma, echoes, and identity. The story follows four young women across different eras, whose lives intersect in the same house, where walls act as resonant chambers for memory. The film employs non-linear time, recurring gestures, and sensory storytelling to explore how the female body preserves history. Schilinski describes the film as an act of remembering, emphasizing perception, shifting perspectives, and emotional suggestion over exposition. It has received critical acclaim, earning eight European Film Award nominations and recognition at the Torino Film Festival. The film will be released in Italian cinemas on February 26, 2026, distributed by I Wonder Pictures. The clip offers a preview of a work that challenges cinematic form and invites audiences to listen as much as to watch.

**Raoul Peck's 'Orwell: 2+2=5' Revisits the Visionary Legacy of George Orwell in a Powerful Documentary**
Raoul Peck's documentary 'Orwell: 2+2=5', set to premiere on February 25, 2026, at the Cannes Film Festival in the Cannes Première section, explores the final months of George Orwell's life and his visionary work, particularly '1984'. Through Orwell's own writings—letters, journals, and texts—presented as a first-person voiceover, the film examines his deep concerns about totalitarianism, racism, social inequality, and threats to freedom. The documentary interweaves archival footage, photographs, film clips, and data to visually connect Orwell’s ideas with contemporary realities. It highlights Orwell’s belief that 'to hate totalitarianism, you must experience it firsthand,' referencing his time in colonial Burma. The film underscores how Orwell’s concepts—such as 'doublethink,' 'newspeak,' 'Big Brother,' and 'thoughtcrime'—remain strikingly relevant today. Peck emphasizes that Orwell foresaw the erosion of objective truth and warns that 'to be corrupted by totalitarianism, it is not necessary to live in a totalitarian state.' The film, featuring voice performances by Eric Ruf and Damian Lewis, is a 2-hour documentary produced in the United States by Le Pacte, serving as a urgent call to vigilance in the face of modern authoritarian tendencies. According to the synopsis, the film 'plunges into the last months of Orwell’s life and his visionary work to explore the roots of the disturbing concepts he revealed in his dystopian masterpiece.'

**Seville Hosts Free Screenings of Finalist Films for the European Parliament's LUX Prize**
Seville will host the first screening session of the five films selected as finalists for the European Parliament's LUX Prize, with the winner to be announced on April 14, 2026, at the European Parliament in Brussels. The films will be shown in Seville at the Cine Cervantes on February 23, and on March 3, 10, 17, and 24. Additional screenings will take place in Almería on March 4 and 18, and April 8 and 22 at the Teatro Apolo. The films will also be projected in multiple cities across Spain—including Barcelona, Cáceres, Gijón, Madrid, Murcia, Oviedo, Pamplona, Port de Sagunt, Sagunt, Salamanca, Santander, Santo Domingo de la Calzada, Segovia, Tarragona, and Zamora—across various dates. A total of 74 screenings are scheduled. The five films are: 'Christy' (Ireland, director Brendan Carty), 'Sorda' (Spain, director Eva Libertad), 'It was just an accidente' (Iran, director Jafar Panahi), 'Love me tender' (France, director Anna Cazenave Cambet), and 'Valor Sentimental' (Norway, director Joachim Trier). Themes include complex family relationships and challenges faced by people with disabilities. The screenings are organized by the European Parliament's Office in Spain (for Oviedo and Santander), the regional office in Barcelona (for Filmoteca de Catalunya), and the Europe Direct network across other cities. Most screenings will occur in Europa Cinemas-affiliated cinemas and public centers. The LUX Prize, a joint initiative of the European Parliament, the European Film Academy, the European Commission, and Europa Cinemas, aims to strengthen ties between EU institutions and citizens by enabling public voting. The final winner is determined by a 50-50 split between public votes and votes from Members of the European Parliament. Audiences can rate the films via the official website until April 2026, with participants eligible for a lottery offering prizes including attendance at the award ceremony in Brussels.

**Berlinale 2026: 'Family and Intimacy Under Pressure' at the Heart of the Selection**
The 76th Berlin International Film Festival, running from February 12 to 22, 2026, opens with a diverse selection of nearly 200 films from over 80 countries, emphasizing European cinema, female directors, and themes of family and intimacy under pressure. Director Tricia Tuttle, in her second edition at the helm, highlights that the festival reflects the current state of global cinema, with recurring motifs of how personal lives are shaped by broader political and social forces. The festival will award an Honorary Golden Bear to Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh, Oscar-winning for her role in 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' in 2023. Women filmmakers are prominently featured: a slight majority of selected films are directed by women, and nine of the 22 official competition entries are by female directors—more than in Cannes or Venice. The opening film, 'No Good Men' by Afghan director Shahrbanoo Sadat, is her third feature and reflects the experiences of Afghan women, a story made possible only through her work. Sadat fled Afghanistan after the Taliban takeover in 2021 and now lives in Hamburg. The festival continues to struggle with attracting major American productions, as high-budget, auteur-driven films are increasingly bypassing festivals in favor of controlled, studio-led releases. Tricia Tuttle notes that such films, like 'One More Battle', 'Sinners', and 'Marty Supreme', are no longer premiering at festivals due to risks of negative reviews and loss of control. Instead, the festival emphasizes European co-productions, with films such as Joachim Trier’s 'A Very Human Story'—co-financed by Norway, Denmark, France, and Germany—showcasing collaborative models. Streaming platforms remain largely absent; only one Netflix film, a Mexican documentary about a woman fabricating pregnancy to avoid family pressure, is featured in a parallel section, underscoring the festival’s commitment to theatrical exhibition as a core value.

**AI Film Festival 'WAIFF' to Launch in Kyoto, Japan in March 2026 with Ise Marie and KENTO MORI as Official Ambassadors**
The World AI Film Festival (WAIFF), the world's first and largest international film festival dedicated to artificial intelligence, is set to be held in Kyoto, Japan, from March 12–13, 2026. This marks the first time WAIFF is being hosted in Japan, as part of the 'Road to WAIFF Cannes 2026' global pre-selection tour, which includes stops in São Paulo (Brazil), Seoul (South Korea), Wuxi (China), and Kyoto (Japan). The festival will feature diverse categories such as short and feature films, vertical micro-series for social media, advertising videos, and script-plus-AI teasers, promoting collaborative storytelling between humans and AI. Organized by the Alpes-Maritimes department in France and the EuropIA Institute, WAIFF aims to bridge technological innovation and artistic expression. The event has appointed voice actress Ise Marie and global dancer artist KENTO MORI as official ambassadors. Ise will participate in the purple carpet and award presentation, and attend the Cannes edition in April 2026 as a global ambassador, while KENTO MORI will perform at the opening ceremony in Kyoto. The deadline for film submissions is February 15, 2026 (Japan time). The judging panel includes prominent figures such as Ryōichi Wada (TOKYO EPIC), Daiki Sakurai (Salmonder), Yuichirō Saitō (Studio Chizu), Fumiko Nomi (translator), Otsu (author), Kenji Qin (author, screenwriter, director), Shin'ya Nakajima (CM director), and Kumiko Endō (writer, visionary creator). Ise expressed that WAIFF offers a transformative opportunity to explore new values in expression, while KENTO MORI emphasized the historic significance of launching this movement from Kyoto, calling for collective steps toward realizing dreams in a new era of storytelling.

**Ten Films to Be Screened at the Télérama Festival in Cholet from January 21 to 27, 2026**
The Télérama film festival will return to the CGR des Arcades Rougé cinema in Cholet (Maine-et-Loire) from January 21 to 27, 2026. Héléna Antunes, director of the CGR, noted that each year the festival aims to include films previously unshown that have been frequently requested by regular patrons. This year, ten films will be screened, including three world premieres: 'The Mastermind', 'Promis le Ciel', and 'Le gâteau du Président'. The selection features impactful films such as 'Sirat', which won the Jury Prize at the Cannes Film Festival, and 'L'Agent secret' and 'Une bataille après l'autre' by Paul Thomas Anderson, starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Sean Penn. A warning is issued for these three films due to violent, bloody scenes and intense atmospheres that may disturb younger audiences. Other films include 'La Trilogie d'Oslo / Amour', which competed at the Venice Film Festival, and 'Nino' starring William Leghbill, about a young man facing a major challenge and two urgent missions that lead him through Paris, helping him reconnect with others and himself. 'Partir un jour', a musical featuring Juliette Armanet and Bastien Bouillon, previously enchanted Cannes in its opening. Lastly, 'Miroir n°3', a German drama, follows Laura, a Berlin student who survives a car accident but is emotionally traumatized; she is taken in by Betty, a witness to the crash, and gradually forms a familial bond with Betty’s husband and son, though unresolved pasts eventually resurface, forcing Laura to confront her own life.

**Cannes Critics' Week Highlights 10 Filmmakers for Feature Development Program Next Step**
Cannes Critics' Week has announced the 10 filmmakers selected for its 12th edition of the Next Step feature development program, which runs from December 6–12, 2025, culminating in an Industry Day in Paris. The initiative supports directors who previously showcased short films at Critics' Week, with a focus on diverse, emerging voices. This year’s cohort includes projects from Estonia, Ireland, Mexico, France, the Netherlands, Brazil, Malaysia, and the Philippines. Notable projects include Anna Hints’ 'Black Hairy Beast,' a mythological romantic drama blending Indian and Estonian folklore; Róisín Burns’ 'Happy Hardcore,' a story of a deserter from the Iraq War returning to England; Marinthia Gutiérrez’s 'Nabor,' set in 1950s Tijuana; Marie Larrivé’s animated 'Erika,' a 1999-set revenge thriller in Brittany; Carmen Leroi’s 'L'Expérience impossible,' a time-travel love story; Robert-Jonathan Koeyers’ 'Story of August,' a 2D animated film on identity and family trauma; Leonardo Martinelli’s 'Fantasma Neon,' a musical exploring the gig economy in Rio de Janeiro; Ribeiro’s 'Saturday in Copacabana,' a dreamlike romantic comedy set in Rio; Juan Pablo Villalobos’ 'Ladrones de cuadros,' a contemplative crime comedy in Oaxaca; and Ananth Subramaniam’s 'Pray to the Thunder,' a punk-rock rebellion tale in Malaysia. The program includes the new Next Step Sooner Prize, offering a €2,500 grant and a Cannes Festival invitation, with the winner announced in May 2026. The selection features half women directors and strong representation from Latin America, with two projects from Mexico and two from Brazil. The initiative continues its partnership with SACEM for music scoring and will launch Next Step Studio in 2026 with Indonesia as the focus, in collaboration with KawanKawan Media. Thomas Rosso, Programme Manager, affirmed the program’s success and its commitment to diversity and emerging talent.

**Two Film Festivals Succeed Each Other in Carmaux, Featuring Cult Actor Benoît Delépine**
Carmaux (Tarn) will host two consecutive film festivals in November 2025. First, the 11th edition of the Cinema Social and Workers' Film Festival at Clap Ciné, running from November 14 to 16, 2025, will feature several highly anticipated premieres. The festival's centerpiece is 'Animal Totem,' a film by cult director Benoît Delépine, who will attend the opening night screening on Friday, November 14 at 20:30. Delépine has a special connection to Clap Ciné, as one of its screening rooms is named after him and Gustave Kervern, his longtime collaborator. Delépine previously filmed 'En même temps' in Carmaux in 2021, including a scene shot at the town’s town hall. Other major premieres include 'Ceux qui comptent' (national release March 18, 2026), starring Sandrine Kiberlain and Pierre Lottin, with director Jean-Baptiste Leonetti present on Sunday, November 16 at 16:30; 'Howard Zinn, une histoire populaire des États-Unis 2,' with Daniel Mermet and Olivier Azam on stage Saturday, November 15 at 20:30; and 'Dossier 137,' a Cannes official selection thriller, screening Saturday at 17:00. Additional films include 'Ma frère' with Amel Bent, 'Les Braises' with Virginie Efira, and re-releases of 'Les Quatre saisons d'Espigoule' and 'Les Copains du dimanche' with Jean-Paul Belmondo. Following this, Clap Ciné will host the first edition of Carmanga, a Japanese animation festival, from November 21 to 23, 2025, featuring screenings, workshops, stalls, and cosplay.

**49th Mostra International Film Festival Announces 15 Oscar Pre-Selections**
The 49th edition of the Mostra Internacional de Cinema de São Paulo has announced 15 films selected by their respective countries as official entries for the Best International Feature Film category at the Oscars. This year’s lineup includes 'O Agente Secreto' by Kleber Mendonça Filho (Brazil/France/Netherlands/Germany), which will be screened ahead of its wider release, following the pattern of 'Ainda Estou Aqui' in 2024. Other notable entries are 'Foi Apenas um Acidente' by Jafar Panahi (France), representing France; 'No Other Choice' by Park Chan-wook (South Korea); 'Sirât' by Oliver Laxe (Spain/France), chosen as the festival's opening film; and 'Palestina 36' by Annemarie Jacir (Palestine/UK/France/Denmark). The selection also features films from Sweden ('Águias da República'), Iceland ('O Amor que Resta'), Egypt ('Feliz Aniversário'), Croatia ('Fiume o Morte!'), India ('Homebound'), Belgium ('Jovens Mães'), Taiwan ('Left-Handed Girl'), Lebanon ('Um Mundo Triste e Belo'), Iraq ('The President's Cake'), and Germany ('O Som da Queda'), which won the Jury Prize at Cannes. The event runs from October 16 to October 30, 2025, across multiple venues in São Paulo, with screening dates and times listed for each film. The article notes that this year’s selection marks a continuation of Brazil’s Oscar success, following the country’s first win with 'Ainda Estou Aqui'.
